title: Experimental Officer – Mass Spectrometry
text:
College of Life & Environmental Sciences 
This new full-time post is available from 1 October 2015 on a fixed-term basis for three years. 
Many people dream about combining their passion with their job; at the University of Exeter we make this a reality. With over 19,000 students and 4,300 members of staff (employed over 3 campuses), the opportunity to embark on a career that you are passionate about is available in a variety of non-academic roles. While traditional academic roles still underpin what we do, we have an increasing requirement for talented and passionate people to support our academics in what are known as Technical roles. 
The post holder will be responsible for the day-to-day running, maintenance and development of the mass spectrometry (MS) facility. The key responsibilities of the role will be; to operate, maintain and develop the MS facility and associated instrumentation; to assist MS facility users with sample analysis, method development, and preparation of grant applications and research publications; to generally assist colleagues in their MS related research activities and to plan, co-ordinate and implement research programmes in collaboration with MS facility users. 
We need a team of talented individuals to support our teaching and research, and in training the next generation of top scientists. Our technical roles all focus on different aspects of science - from mechanical/electrical engineering to cutting edge research, but all benefit from the same investment in science here at the University of Exeter. 
Diversity of skills 
The University of Exeter believes that the best teams are composed of a variety of experiences and we are therefore passionate about recruiting people from a diversity of backgrounds. 
Our women in HE work extends the principles of the Athena SWAN Charter and the Gender Equality Charter Mark to all roles in the University. At Exeter we are committed to bringing the best development experience to women at all stages of their careers as well as being passionate about promoting careers for women in science. That is why we have invested in a range of initiatives, online resources, networking, training and mentoring opportunities to encourage women to reach their full potential. 
Before submitting an application you may wish to discuss the post further by contacting Professor Nicholas Smirnoff, Professor of Plant Biochemistry and Director of MS Facility, telephone (01392 725168) or email N.Smirnoff@exeter.ac.uk or Dr Elizabeth James, Technical Services, email E.J.James@exeter.ac.uk 
A list of equipment, software, data analysis pipelines and services currently offered by the facility can be obtained from Professor Smirnoff on request. To find out more about the role with the Job Description and Person Specification, please click here 
The University of Exeter is an equal opportunity employer which is 'Positive about Disabled People'. Whilst all applicants will be judged on merit alone, we particularly welcome applications from groups currently underrepresented in the workforce. Share this job
